opened_prs.title: feat(proxy): add optional forward-url for l2 client and builder
opened_prs.body:
Adds the following optional CLI arguments to `BuilderArgs` and `L2ClientArgs`
- `forward-url`
- `forward-jwt-token`
- `forward-jwt-path`

If left unspecified the `forward-url` for the builder, and the l2 client will default to the engine-API RPC endpoint making this change backwards compatible. 

Rationale:
Depending on the use case forwarded requests may be better suited to hit the HTTP API of the L2 Client, and the builder. 

For Example:
- `eth_sendRawTransactionConditional` only exists on the EthAPI, and not the engine-API on `op-geth` making rollup-boost incompatible with forwarding conditional 4337 transactions to the builder, and the sequencer.

repo.name: rollup-boost
repo.description: Proxy server for the Ethereum Engine API

opened_prs.title: Better LRU and Fix for Deadlock
opened_prs.body:
I discovered a deadlock in the rollup boost server. I've posted a fix here using a concurrent, lock free LRU cache. In general this should make the code here more readable and less prone to errors.

As a general note, I've noticed that the way mutex locks are being handled in this code base seems to be pretty fast and loose. There were several cases where locks were being held far longer than they need to be.

repo.name: rollup-boost
repo.description: FORK: Sidecar to Enable Rollup Extensions

opened_prs.title: Add chaos testing
opened_prs.body:
This is still a draft since the setup is not that good yet.

The idea is that we can use a setup to deploy an Op-stack network (with Rollup-boost) and then create a unit test to deploy a reth builder with a proxy in front using the same utilities we use for integration tests.

Once that is done, we can randomly add delays and drop connections from the proxy to simulate chaos. Our success criteria is that even in this scenario, the liveness of the chain is not affected (there is a block every n seconds).

To deploy this setup you have to:

Run [this branch](https://github.com/ferranbt/optimism/tree/fb-v1.10.0) for the legacy op-stack docker-compose setup:
```
$ make devnet-up
```

Run `rollup-boost`:
```
$ cargo run -- --l2-url http://localhost:8551 --builder-url http://localhost:4444 --l2-jwt-token 688f5d737bad920bdfb2fc2f488d6b6209eebda1dae949a8de91398d932c517a --builder-jwt-token 688f5d737bad920bdfb2fc2f488d6b6209eebda1dae949a8de91398d932c517a
```

Run the unit test:
```
$ cargo test --features integration -- integration::integration_test::tests::test_integration_chaos --show-output --nocapture
```

Note that in the current unit test the genesis path is hardcoded to my computer. You would have to change that to test this.

My current thoughts:
- We should not use the docker-compose setup since it is a legacy system though I am not a fan of Kurtosis.
- The setup gets (way) more complicated if we have first to create a local Rollup-boost docker image and then run Kurtosis.

opened_prs.title: Add support for multiple builder and block selection

closed_prs.title: docs: Add book for rollup-boost
closed_prs.body: Use Reth's book template to create GitHub Pages for rollup boost docs.

closed_prs.title: chore: allow configuration of debug server listen address
closed_prs.body:
### Description
Allow the configuration of the address which the debug server listens on. There are certain runtimes (e.g. docker compose), where each container is in its own networking space and to be able to communicate between the containers requires services to listen on `0.0.0.0` instead of `127.0.0.1`.

I've kept the default as `127.0.0.1` as it works on k8s and is the most restrictive.

closed_prs.title: chore: remove verbose println
closed_prs.body:
### Description 
Remove verbose println! on each FCU call

closed_prs.title: chore: argument to set execution
closed_prs.body:
### Description
Add a CLI argument `--execution-mode` to allow users to set the execution mode on startup. Currently when deploying a new sequencer, we:

1. Start a new node
2. Restore a snapshot
3. Sync the node top tip
4. Do a handover from the old sequencer to the new

In this flow, it would be ideal to start rollup boost on the new node with exeuciton-mode=disabled, then on the handover (step 4) set the execution mode to enabled.

opened_issues.title: Bug: `proxy::forward_request: error reading body error=Malformed request`
opened_issues.body:
#119 Added a change that breaks the Proxy Layers forwarding of requests.

The first request from `op-node` fails to hit the l2 client because of errors coming from `http_helpers::read_body`

Source of the issue: https://github.com/flashbots/rollup-boost/blob/a9a64fad75c1ada181ea7b8d55c85bfacf3922ce/src/proxy.rs#L221C35-L221C58

The first request from `op-node` that is failing is `eth_chainId ` resulting in: `2025-03-10 12:07:47 2025-03-10T19:07:47.857538Z  WARN proxy::forward_request: error reading body error=Malformed request`

This error is bubbled up, so `op-node` immediately shuts down as it never gets a response from the l2 client. 

This can be reproduced by building the latest docker image on main, and pulling the image into `optimism-package`

opened_issues.title: Rollup Boost Status Page
opened_issues.body:
Similar to how MEV-boost relays offer a [status page](https://boost-relay.flashbots.net/) which shows their registered validators, most recently received payloads, and more, we should have something like this on rollup boost which the sequencer can run which shows how many block builders are delivering payloads, as well as latencies, and eventually likely some other relevant features around flashblocks. Details about the block builder and TEE attestations also may be servable over this component but likely not done inside of the rollup boost logic.

The implementation of this is likely that rollup boost stores the data in-memory for the sequencer window and offers it to another service that indexes the data to make it available to a webpage that end users can go to.

wartime_milady_ceo_summary: - PR #129 and #128: Introduced Vercel support and created GitHub Pages for Rollup Boost documentation using Reth's book template, enhancing the accessibility and presentation of project documentation.

- PR #124: Enabled configuration of the debug server's listening address, allowing flexibility for runtime environments like Docker Compose by permitting services to listen on `0.0.0.0` instead of `127.0.0.1`.
